knowledge_graph.title: Mental Health Act 2007
knowledge_graph.description: The Mental Health Act 2007 is an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom. It amended the Mental Health Act 1983 and the Mental Capacity Act 2005. It applies to people residing in England and Wales. Most of the Act was implemented on 3 November 2008.
knowledge_graph.introduced_by: Lord Warner, the Department of Health and the Home Office.

related_questions.question: What is the purpose of the Mental Health Act?
related_questions.snippet: The Mental Health Act is a law that tells people with a mental health disorder what their rights are and how they can be treated. The term "mental health disorder" is used to describe people who have: a mental illness. a learning disability.

related_questions.question: What was the mental health in 2007?
related_questions.snippet: Results: The prevalence of any lifetime mental disorder was 45.5%. The prevalence of any 12 month mental disorder was 20.0%, with anxiety disorders (14.4%) the most common class of mental disorder followed by affective disorders (6.2%) and substance use disorders (5.1%).
related_questions.title: 2007 National Survey of Mental Health and Wellbeing - PubMed

related_questions.question: What did the mental health Systems Act do?
related_questions.snippet: The Mental Health Systems Act of 1980 (MHSA) was United States legislation signed by President Jimmy Carter which provided grants to community mental health centers. During the following Ronald Reagan administration, the United States Congress repealed most of the law.
